TO:Via E-Mail Transmission
Director, Regulatory Management Division

United States Department of Homeland Security
111 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., 3rd Floor

FROM:
CENTRO ROMERO, a BIA Recognized and Accredited Not-For-Profit
6216 North Clark Street

RE:DHS Docket Number USCIS-2006-0044.

COMMENT on Proposed Rule to Adjust the Immigration and Naturalization Benefit
Application and Petition Fee Schedule, Published at 72 Fed. Reg. 4888 (02-01-
2007).

This Comment is submitted in accordance with those guidelines
provided at 72 Fed. Reg. 4888 (February 1, 2007). This Comment is due on or
before April 2, 2007. Thank you for this opportunity and for taking our Comment
under your careful consideration.

CONCLUSIONS.
?The Proposed Rule exceeds the relevant statutory authority and may
not be legally promulgated as a Final Rule in its current form.
?The position advanced by United States Citizenship & Immigration
Services (USCIS) leadership and adopted in the Proposed Rule as if it were a
mandate, that Congressional appropriation for USCIS operations is not an option,
is erroneous and can find no support in law or fact. Not only is Congressional
appropriation allowed for all public and governmental activities, but also it is
absolutely vital.
oIt is the job of USCIS leadership to lobby for and obtain necessary
appropriations to run its agency and execute its mission.
oIt is the role of Congress to adequately fund the public and
governmental activities of executive branch agencies, including the USCIS, that
are created by Congressional action.
?The Proposed Rule fundamentally departs from Federal methodologies
and guidelines for establishing user fees for special benefits, as established by the
Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Federal Accounting Standards
Advisory Board (FASAB), and instead creates an unconscionable fee schedule,
not to support the Immigration Examinations Fees Account (IEFA), but to carry an
entire Federal executive branch agency into the 21st Century.
?The Proposed Rule incorrectly and improperly determines ?full cost? of
immigration adjudication and naturalization services, and purports to include many
public and governmental activities and objectives that are not lawfully covered by
the Immigration Examinations Fee Account (IEFA).
?The arguments advanced by the Proposed Rule for automatically
including interim benefits into adjustment of status applications are circular and
unpersuasive. Interim benefits should remain the Applicant?s choice.
?The proposal to include VAWA and T-visa costs into the surcharge pool
is acceptable and desirable.

I.THE PROPOSED RULE EXCEEDS AND VIOLATES THE
APPLICABLE STATUTORY AUTHORITY.
The Proposed Rule exceeds and violates the applicable statutory authority that
allows the Department of Homeland Security (USDHS) to establish an account for
Immigration Examinations Fees (the Immigration Examinations Fees Account
or ?IEFA?). 8 U.S.C. 1356(m) (2006). This provision is the exclusive statutory
authority given to the appropriate federal agency, presumably the USCIS, to
charge user fees, and the Proposed Rule purports to cite no other authority.

a.The IEFA Authority Granted in 8 U.S.C. ? 1356 is Not a Congressional
Mandate.
The authority granted to the USCIS to charge fees to fund the IEFA is
discretionary, and does not constitute a congressional mandate for USCIS to
become a ?fee-based agency? or to charge user-fees at all. Fees may be
established and charged exclusively to provide special benefits applied for by
identifiable individual recipients, specifically, ?immigration adjudication and
naturalization services.? See 8 U.S.C. 1356(n) (2006).
Section 1356(m) states, ?fees for providing adjudication and naturalization
services may be set at a level that will ensure recovery of the full costs of providing
all such services ? .? Clearly, USCIS has Congressional permission to charge
fees, and then, specifically to recover the full costs of ?providing adjudication and
naturalization services,? not to run an entire federal agency.
The only mandate stated in Section 1356(m) has to do with the disposition of
any such IEFA funds that may have been charged and collected: they ?shall be
deposited as offsetting receipts into a separate account entitled ?Immigration
Examinations Fee Account? in the Treasury of the United States ? .? As well, the
disposition of any IEFA fees that may be collected in the Virgin Islands or in
Guam ?shall be paid over to the treasury of the Virgin Islands and to the treasury of
Guam, ? .?
The USCIS has not been mandated, at any time, to become a user-fee
supported federal agency. Such an assertion is simply not true. The USCIS
interpretation or allegation that the Congressionally-allowed establishment of the
IEFA is a Congressional mandate to convert the USCIS into a user-fee run
agency, with no appropriation options available, is not supportable, but is,
nevertheless, unmistakably articulated by the USDHS / USCIS. See, for example,
USCIS Office of Communications, Questions and Answers, # 18 (January 31,
2007) [?Congress created a user fee account for the former INS in 1988,
transforming it into a fee-based agency. As a fee-based agency, USCIS uses
revenue from application fees [IEFA] rather than appropriated funds to pay for the
administration of the nation?s immigration laws, processing of applications, and the
infrastructure needed to support these activities.?] Emphasis added. See also the
remarks of Dr. Emilio T. Gonzalez, USCIS Director, in the January 31, 2007
USCIS Press Conference:
"MS MONTENEGRO:Is there any possibility that Congress could
create a budget? Have you addressed that issue?
MR. GONZALEZ:I do not, because, you know, we have a mandate
that we are a self-sustaining, fee-based agency, and I have not in my conversation
with Congress ever gone and asked for an appropriation. At this point, I have no
intention of doing so."
TAPE TRANSCRIPTION, Press Conference on a USCIS Proposed Fee
Restructure, Building an Immigration Service for the 21st Century, pp. 14-15
(USDHS / USCIS January 31, 2007).
Congress itself has questioned this assertion. In a February 13, 2007 letter to
USDHS Secretary Chertoff, Representative Zoe Lofgren (D-CA) expressed concern
over some of the Secretary?s testimony during a Homeland Security Committee
hearing. Representative Lofgren?s letter states:
"During the hearing, I asked you if you would be prepared to move toward a
request for appropriation for appropriate needs if the recent proposed fee increase
for immigration applications fails. You answered, ?That would be a problem. My
understanding is that Congress has always mandated this fee.?
I would greatly appreciate clarification of your statement as Congress has
simply authorized, not mandated, the collection of fees to cover costs of
immigration application processing. [Footnote citing Section 1356(m) is omitted].
In fact, as you know, DHS has received appropriations in the past for this program,
most recently $182 million in FY07. Such appropriations belie your explanation of
a mandated fee recovery.
I am also concerned about your response to my question about the significant
drop in funding you requested for FY08. You stated that the drop in the USCIS
budget was due to the proposed fee increase of 66% for processing naturalization
and immigration applications. You stated, ?If the fee were blocked, then we would
have a big hole in the budget. That would be a big problem for this Congress
because you would have to find a significant chunk of money. Either we would
have to go back to the days of backlog, or we would have to decide to hire fewer
Border Patrols or have less technology.?
I would appreciate a clarification of your statement. USCIS immigration
application fees cannot be used for enforcement purposes. [Footnote citing
Section 1356(n) is omitted]. Yet you suggested that without a fee increase,
USCIS may not be able to fund additional Border Patrol agents, despite the fact
that Congress has been steadily funding this for the past several years without a
fee increase.
Please provide me with clarification on your understanding of fee collection by
USCIS, why the USCIS budget was cut and for what purpose the increased fees
amounts will be used."

Letter to Secretary Chertoff from Representative Zoe Lofgren, Chair of the House
Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, Citizenship, Refugees, Border Security
and International Law (February 13, 2007), published as a Press Release at,
http://www.house.gov/apps/list/press/cal_16lofgren.
The USCIS assertion that Congress has somehow prohibited the USDHS /
USCIS from seeking appropriations because Congress has allowed the IEFA fund
is indeed strange, especially in light of Section 1356(n) which explicitly states, ?All
deposits into the ?Immigration Examinations Fee Account? shall remain available
until expended to the Attorney General to reimburse any appropriation the amount
paid out of such appropriation for expenses in providing immigration adjudication
and naturalization services ? .? Emphasis added. Not only does subsection (n)
explicitly indicate that Congressional appropriations are possible and expected,
but it also indicates that such Congressional appropriations remain available, not
only to meet public and governmental goals, but also for ?providing immigration
adjudication and naturalization services.?

b.Revenue Streams Available to the USCIS.
The USCIS has, its assertions to the contrary notwithstanding, at least two
revenue streams available: (1) Congressional appropriations must be requested
and provided to sustain the agency?s public service mission and its governmental
operating requirements. Congressional appropriations, in fact, as evidenced by the
language of Section 1356(n), may even be requested for immigration and
naturalization adjudications and processing (with provisions for reimbursement).
(2) IEFA may be funded with user fees but only for immigration and naturalization
adjudications and processing.
What is more troubling, however, is the fact that USDHS / USCIS has
deliberately asked Congress for less money based upon this fictitious assertion.
The Lofgren Letter indicates that USDHS had asked for $30 million for 2008, in
stark contrast to $182 million for 2007 and $114 million for 2006.
USDHS / USCIS articulates a real ?problem? for Congress if the ?problem? is
not borne on the shoulders of immigration and naturalization applicants. It then
threatens backlogs, dangerous understaffing, and an operational inability to move
the USCIS into the 21st Century. What USDHS / USCIS does not state, however,
is that the ?problem? is one which is self-created by the agency?s failure to notify
Congress of its operational and mission requirements and ask for the required
appropriations to meet its mission and mandate.
The USCIS failure to proactively seek adequate Congressional appropriations
to bring the USCIS into the 21st Century is, in fact, not mandated, is certainly
troubling, and may actually impair its ability to meet its national security
mandates. This is a governmental problem that must be solved by the Agency
and the Congress. It most certainly has nothing to do with processing immigration
and naturalization benefits applications.
A Federal Executive Branch Agency created by legislation, such as the
USCIS, must be sustained by Congressional funding. It is the Agency?s
responsibility to notify Congress of its operating requirements and mission goals,
and it is the responsibility of Congress to fund the mission and operations of the
Agency that it has mandated.
It is unacceptable for an agency to fail to identify and ask Congress for all
required funding, as USDHS / USCIS has apparently done. It is statutorily
impermissible for the USCIS to build funding for public and governmental mandates
and objectives from the IEFA (specifically for processing special benefits for
identifiable individual applicants).

c.The Scope of the IEFA.
The IEFA is explicitly specific in its scope. Fees from individual recipients of
special benefits may be collected:
?To recover the full costs of providing ?adjudication and naturalization
services;?
?To recover ?the costs of similar services provided without charge to
asylum applicants or other immigrants? (surcharges); and
?To recover ?any additional costs associated with the administration of
the fees collected.?
The IEFA is confined exclusively to recovering the full costs of
providing ?special benefits? to identifiable individual recipients, and the costs of
handling the IEFA itself. Such fees, or charges, should not be made ?for a service
when the identification of the specific beneficiary is obscure, and the service can
be considered primarily as benefiting broadly the general public.? See Office of
Management and Budget, Circular No. A-25, 6 and 6(a)(4) [OMB Cir. A-25].
Applications for visas, in fact, are explicitly included in the OMB definition
of ?special benefits.? OMB Cir. A-25, 6(a)(1)(c).
Running an executive branch agency, executing an agency mission, general
agency overhead and operation costs, executing the laws of the United States,
or ?Building an Immigration Service for the 21st Century,? are governmental and
public goals that may not and cannot be financed from the IEFA. Contra USCIS
Office of Communications, Questions and Answers (January 31, 2007).

II.THE PROPOSED RULE FAILS TO PROPERLY IMPLEMENT THE
APPLICABLE FEDERAL ACCOUNTING GUILDELINES.
The Proposed Rule purports to comply with guidelines outlined by the Office of
Management and Budget (OMB) and of the Federal Accounting Standards
Advisory Board (FASAB). 72. Fed. Reg. 4888, at 4889.

d.OMB and FASAB Guidelines: Special Benefits Activities.
The Proposed Rule correctly states that OMB Circular A-25 (OMB A-
25) ?establishes Federal policy regarding fees assessed for Government services
and the basis upon which federal agencies set user charges sufficient to recover
the full cost to the Federal Government.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4887, 4889. However, the
Proposed Rule neglects to state for which Federal activities it is allowed to recover
the full costs via user fees.
OMB A-25 states its purpose to establish Federal policy for fees assessed for
government services, and it ?provides information on the scope and type of
activities subject to user charges.? OMB A-25 1. It may be applied only to
those ?Federal activities that convey special benefits to recipients beyond those
accruing to the general public.? OMB A-25 3(a). This clearly indicates that any
analysis about costs must begin with an analysis of which activities are involved.
An Agency cannot, therefore, lump its entire operation into user fees, simply
because some of its activities may involve special benefits.
OMB A-25 6 defines the fundamental concept of ?special benefits,? which
are ?derived from Federal activities beyond those received by the general public.?
The Guidelines also state, ?No charge should be made for a service when the
identification of the specific beneficiary is obscure, and the service can be
considered primarily as benefiting broadly the general public.? OMB A-25 6(a)(4).
OMB A-25 goes on to describe how to calculate the ?full cost? of providing special
benefits to identifiable recipients. OMB A-25 6(d). The Proposed Rule, however,
jumps directly to this concept, without first applying the OMB threshold concepts
of ?special benefits? to an analysis of which of the many USCIS activities are:
?Public service activities (no fees can be charged),
?Governmental objectives (can be considered primarily as benefiting
broadly the general public, and any identification of any specific beneficiary is
obscure, at best ? no fees can be charged), and
?Special benefits for an identifiable recipient (a user charge may be
imposed, here pursuant to Section 1356(m)).

e.The Fundamental Flaw in the Proposed Rule.
The USCIS Proposed Rule muddles two very distinct accounting issues:
?Calculating the ?full cost? of the ?activities;? and
?Determining which USCIS ?activities? are covered by the IEFA.
The fundamental flaw in the Proposed Rule is the USCIS failure to make these two
determinations separately, and its failure to make the latter determination first.
USCIS, instead, calculates the full cost of activities to be recovered by the IEFA
by including in the calculation many component agency activities, objectives, and
goals, that are not covered and may not properly be covered by IEFA.
This skewed analysis results in an artificial and impermissible inflation of
the ?full costs? of ?immigration adjudication and naturalization services? to include
the costs for governmental and public activities, which dramatically higher than the
costs associated exclusively with the special benefits delivered to identifiable
individual recipients of ?immigration adjudication and naturalization services.?
IEFA, the USCIS? exclusive statutory authority to charge any fees, clearly and
without doubt has to do only with special benefits applied for by identifiable
individuals.
A narrow group of USCIS activities identified in the Proposed Rule are, in fact,
related to ?special benefits? to ?identifiable recipients,? pursuant to the
requirements of OMB Circular A-25. Unfortunately, USCIS has failed to separate
out these Agency activities in its Proposed Rule, and has instead muddled them
together all the activities involved in running the agency (for example, recruiting
and training activities) with a distinct and limited group of activities, which actually
confer special benefits on identifiable users (for example, sending John Q. Public?s
immigration documents by mail to John Q. Public).
In addition to OMB Circular A-25, USCIS cites FASAB Statement No. 4 on the
issue of the ?full costs.? In the section of the Executive Summary entitled ?Full
Costs,? FASAB states, ?Reporting entities should report the full costs of outputs in
general purpose financial reports. The full cost of an output produced by a
responsibility segment is the sum of (1) the costs of resources consumed by the
segment that directly or indirectly contribute to the output, and (2) the costs of
identifiable supporting services provided by other responsibility segments within
the reporting entity.?
This FASAB guideline establishes that both direct costs (for example, the
cost of the plastic upon which John Q. Public?s immigration card is printed) and
indirect costs (for example, the cost of the labor of the USCIS contractor that
operates the press while Mr. Public?s card is being made) are components of
the ?full cost? of Mr. Public?s card.
However, the FASAB guideline must be read in conjunction with OMB Circular
A-25, which makes clear that the ?full cost? which may be passed along to the
user is the cost involved in providing that particular special benefit to that particular
identifiable user. In other words, the cost of printing an immigration card for John
Q. Public is correctly passed along to John Q. Public. However, the cost of
establishing, for example, an Individual Learning Account (see 72 Fed. Reg. at
4901) for the operator of the printing press so that he/she will be more invested in
his/her job cannot properly be passed along to John Q. Public, as the Proposed
Rule purports to do. The Individual Learning Account has nothing to do with Mr.
Public?s card, nor his application for the card, nor with any other aspect of Mr.
Public?s special benefit process.

f.OMB and FASAB Guidelines: Direct and Indirect Costs.
It is true that ?indirect costs? as well as ?direct costs? may be included into the
calculation to determine the ?full cost.? This Comment does not dispute OMB and
FASAB guidelines that permit the inclusion of indirect costs of special benefits
activities into the calculations of special benefits fees necessary to recover the full
costs of administering the special benefits to identifiable individuals.
??Full cost? includes all direct and indirect costs to any part of the Federal
Government of providing a good, resource, or service.? OMB Circular A25, 6(d).
The emphasis is added to indicate what part of this definition the Proposed Rule
does not take into account. The Proposed Rule mistakenly reads this definition
of ?full cost? to mean that ?full cost? of every activity it undertakes, including
governmental and public activities, as well as special benefits activities.
As noted above, however, the USCIS improperly ignores OMB and FASAB
guidelines regarding which activities may be included into the analysis. This
fundamental flaw, again, skews the USCIS analysis of indirect costs. The
Proposed Rule correctly identifies ?processing activities? that must be undertaken
to adjudicate ?immigration and naturalization applications? [Inform Public / Capture
Biometrics / Intake / Conduct IBIS / Review Records / Make Determination / Fraud
Detection / Issue Document]. 72 Fed. Reg. 4897.
The Proposed Rule then purports to construe the ?indirect costs? of
processing ?immigration adjudication and naturalization services? rendered to
individuals and covered by IEFA, to include both the direct and indirect costs of
executing and implementing governmental operations and public services. 72 Fed.
Reg. 4898-4902. This skewed logic would purport to run the entire agency on the
IEFA fees, which is statutorily impermissible.
The only indirect costs that may be properly recovered by the IEFA are, again,
those costs that can be related to a special benefit processed for an identifiable
individual. OMB A-25 4(a), 6(a). An example of this is the cost of the FBI
background check. Clearly this is an indirect cost (the USCIS does not bear this
cost directly), but the activity (the FBI background check) is clearly traceable to
an identifiable individual who is applying with the USCIS for a special benefit.
OMB Circular A25, 6. The inclusion of this indirect cost as a cost that can be
recovered by the IEFA is permissible, and such a determination complies with the
OMB and the FASAB guidelines.
On the other end of the spectrum, the direct and indirect costs associated with
maintaining and improving the physical plants and computer and information
structures of the USCIS Service Centers and District Offices cannot be properly
identified with an individual who is applying for a special benefit. It is not
statutorily permissible for the USCIS to recover such infrastructure costs from the
IEFA simply by asserting that such costs are ?indirect.? See OMB A-25 6(a).

g.The Activities Identified by the USCIS Proposed Rule.
As stated above, it is not enough for the USCIS simply to assert, as it
is doing in the Proposed Rule, that everything that it does is a direct or indirect
cost of ?immigration and naturalization applications processing.? In this section of
the Comment, the activities identified in the Proposed Rule we first classify
as ?public? or ?governmental? or as ?special benefits for identifiable recipients,? a
necessary operation not clearly undertaken by the Proposed Rule.
If an activity is classified ?special benefits,? then the full costs of that
activity, including both the direct and indirect costs of that activity, may be
recovered from the IEFA. If, however, the activity is ?public? or ?governmental,?
may not be properly funded from the IEFA. Those activities must be funded by
Congress, which mandated those activities. This is the proper analysis indicated
both by the OMB and the FASAB, and we classify the activities using those
guidelines in OMB A-25 6(a). Once the Agency activities are properly identified
and classified, the full cost of the ?special benefits? activities may be calculated
according to guidelines. FASAB 4, 89-91.
USCIS identifies 27 activities, which it proposes to fund through the
dramatically increased IEFA fees. 72 Fed. Reg. 4888, 4898-4902. Of these 27
activities, only four may be legitimately funded through IEFA because they are, in
fact, related to special benefits for identifiable users:
?Providing change of address data entry services, a $1.2 million cost
item (p. 4898) ;
?Enhancing mail and file room support for the AAO, a $129,000 cost
item (p. 4899);
?Paying increased costs to the FBI for background checks, a $12.4
million cost item (p. 4899); and
?Enhancing delivery of secure documents, a $31.6 million cost item (p.
4899).
The remaining 23 activities in the Proposed Rule?s list of
purported ?processing activities? do not contribute to special benefits for identifiable
users, as outlined in OMB Circular A-25 6(a). Rather, these 23 activities
represent USCIS governmental and public service objectives to bring the USCIS
into the 21st Century. These activities are legitimate, necessary and laudable, but
they may not be funded from IEFA, because they do not relate to special benefits
provided to identifiable recipients. Nowhere in Section 1356(m) of the INA, nor in
OMB A-25, does the USCIS receive authority to refashion itself into a 21st Century
federal agency funded on the IEFA fees. Improving the USCIS must be
accomplished, it is true, but it must be done via Congressional appropriation.
The following is a list of the 23 items listed by the Proposed Rule
as ?processing activities,? which do not, in fact, confer ?special benefits? on
identifiable users. These activities are therefore not subject to user fees, and may
not be legally funded from the IEFA:
(1) Enhance adjudications and support staff (p. 4898): A staffing
model ?designed to align resources with the need to prevent future backlogs?
cannot be related to providing special benefits for identifiable users. The notion
that users of immigration and naturalization services should provide a funding
cushion for unidentifiable future users of such services directly contravenes the
meaning of the OMB A-25 6(a). The USCIS, itself, has characterized the backlog
problem as one involving national security (4892-93), and is clearly a public or
governmental objective.
(2) Process FOIA requests (4898): FOIA requests do not constitute
special benefits for identifiable users that would be contributing to the IEFA. FOIA
requests originate from persons other than applicants for immigration and
naturalization benefits. It may also be problematic if the FOIA law prohibits or
limits charges made. In any event, even if FOIA is considered a special benefit, it
is not one that is included within the scope of the IEFA.
(3) Print and distribute guidebooks for new naturalized citizens (4898-
99): A Citizen?s Almanac containing ?America?s most cherished founding
documents, [and] Presidential quotes on citizenship? does nothing to advance or
process an identifiable recipient?s application and is therefore not within the IEFA.
By definition, the recipient would only receive this unsolicited ?gift? from USCIS
after his/her application has been fully processed and adjudicated. This cost
could be included only if it is upon order of the applicant.
(4) Establish a second full service card production facility (4899):
Building a second production facility for use if the original facility ever
experiences ?catastrophic failure? is another cost item related only to a
governmental objective, not to special services for identifiable users. It is an
infrastructure cost related to a contingency, and it is a sensible governmental
objective; not one that can be related to a special benefit for an identifiable
recipient, and it may not be funded from the IEFA.
(5) Enhance fraud protection and detection efforts (4899): The
activities of the Fraud Detection and National Security Division (described at 4894)
benefit the general public and is commensurate with the USCIS public service
mission, as opposed to identifiable recipients of special benefits. It is an activity
related to executing the Agency?s mission, and as such, is a governmental and
public service objective that may not be funded from the IEFA.
(6) Enhance national security systems and processes (4899): See
item 5 above with respect to fraud detection efforts.
(7) Enhance internal security and investigative operations (4899): This
so-called ?processing activity? would purport to use the IEFA to fund investigations
of misconduct of contractors. It is difficult to conceive of an activity less related to
special benefits for identifiable users of immigration services.
(8) Establish an administrative site inspection program (4900): See
items 5 above with respect to fraud detection efforts.
(9) Enhance protective security operations (4900): Hiring security
guards for USCIS facilities does not confer a special benefit on an identifiable
recipient of immigration services.
(10) Enhance existing card production program (4900): Improving
general efficiency of contractor services does not provide a special benefit for an
identifiable user of immigration services.
(11) Enhance emergency preparedness operations (4900):
Establishing ?full time, real-time mission coordination? is wholly unrelated to
providing a special benefit for an identifiable user.
(12) Enhance personnel security operations (4900): Obtaining security
clearances for USCIS employees and contractors does not provide a special
benefit for an identifiable user.
(13) Fully fund the Cuban Haitian Entrant Program (4900): This activity
is laudable and may arguably be included within the surcharge authority of the
IEFA. However, on closer examination it appears to involve more a governmental
resettlement initiative than individuals applying for special benefits covered by the
IEFA. These expenditures appear to be grants to NGO groups, rather than
application fee waiver cases. Our understanding of the surcharge authority does
not include this type of expenditure, laudable as it is. Surcharges may be
collected for the IEFA for the processing of asylum applications and other fee
waiver cases. This important resettlement activity appears to be a governmental
and public service that must be adequately funded by Congress.
Another objection is the irregular and unpredictable expenditures
involved (clearly admitted by the Proposed Rule). The Proposed Rule has, in
another place, declined inclusion of revenues derived from the TPS, the NACARA
203, and the Section 245(i) programs because their collection cannot any longer
be counted upon. (4897). Here, the Proposed Rule purports to include an
expenditure that is, at once $14 million but also ?unpredictable? and ?irregular.?
(4900).
(14) Upgrade and maintain the USCIS information technology program
(4900-01): Pricing this item at a staggering $124.3 million, the Proposed Rule
seeks to have applicants fund USCIS efforts to bring its IT systems into the 21st
Century. It is difficult to conceive of a governmental objective more suitable for
Congressional appropriation.
(15) Acquire resources for rent and lease acquisition (4901): Rent
does not provide a special benefit for an identifiable recipient, and may not be
funded from the IEFA.
(16) Enhance training program for all USCIS employees to foster
individual achievement (4901): Online training opportunities and ?individual learning
accounts? do not provide special benefits for identifiable users.
(17) Enhance resources for the Office of Chief Counsel (4901): This
item would not provide special benefits for identifiable users.
(18) Transfer records to the National Archives and Records
Administration (4901): Inventorying and managing records do not provide special
benefits for identifiable users. On the other hand, the cost of retrieving and moving
an applicant?s file in the processing of his/her case may be included in the
calculation of the full cost of adjudicating that applicant?s special benefit case.
That cost, to be sure, is not $3.4 million dollars, but with handling and postage,
probably is more in the neighborhood of $15.00 or less. Moreover, this records
management improvement may be mandated, as NARA asserts (4901), and
certainly could not be funded by IEFA, but would have to find appropriation.
(19) Fully fund the H.R. and OSHS Programs (4901): Providing every
supervisor in the agency with occupational health and safety training may benefit
agency employees but does not provide special benefits for identifiable users.
(20) Conduct policy evaluation and research (4901-02): Conducting
policy evaluation and research is an excellent example of an activity which
benefits the general public, but it does not provide special benefits for identifiable
users.
(21) Enhance resources for Office of CFO (4902): See comment for
Item 17 above.
(22) Establish a national recruitment program for federal employees
(4902): Recruiting individuals to work for USCIS is a general business cost and
does not provide special benefits for identifiable users.
(23) Enhance procurement operations (4902): Another necessary
governmental function, but it does not provide special benefits for identifiable users.

III.IEFA SURCHARGE AUTHORITY, VAWA AND RELATED CRIME-
VICTIM VISAS.
The USCIS authority to calculate surcharges and add them to other
special benefits application fees to cover costs of Asylum and other fee-waiver
cases is clearly provided in the IEFA. 8 U.S.C. 1356(m).
The Proposed Rule ?assumes no revenues from applications for T
nonimmigrant status [Form I-914], or self-petitions [Form I-360] under the Violence
Against Women Act of 1994 (VAWA), ? .? 72 Fed. Reg. 4897. The Proposed
Rule would change the fee for filing Form I-914, for trafficking victims, from $270.00
to no fee. It would also change the fee for filing Form I-360, for victims of domestic
violence and Amerasians, from $190.00 to no fee. Other I-360 filers would have to
pay an application fee.
This Comment supports these particular innovations. Most, if not all, T-
visa applicants and VAWA self-petitioners are in circumstances that would allow
for fee waivers, and by making these proposed changes, the USCIS would
ultimately save time and resources that would otherwise be expended in
adjudicating these fee waiver requests.
Similar logic, it would seem, may apply to widows and at least some special
immigrants. Widowers and Special Immigrants who file Form I-360 will
presumably be subject to paying the filing fee, and should be able to continue to
apply for fee waivers, if qualified. This Comment therefore urges that 8 C.F.R.
103.7(c)(5) continue to list Form I-360 filers as being eligible to file for a waiver of
fees.

IV.ADJUSTMENT OF STATUS AND INTERIM BENEFITS.
The Proposed Rule seeks to ?merge the fees for certain applications so
applicants will pay a single fee rather than paying several fees for related
services.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4888. For example, applicants for Adjustment of Status
(Form I-485, current fee $325) may currently apply for interim benefits, such as
employment authorization (Form I-765, current fee $180) and permission to travel
abroad (Form I-131, current fee $170), while their main application is pending.
USCIS ?estimates that the current application fees paid by an applicant for
adjustment of status with interim benefits over a multi-year time period are
approximately $800.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4894.
This proposal should not be implemented for three reasons: (1) many
applicants will not need these interim benefits and should not be forced to pay a
built-in charge for benefits they either do not need or want; (2) some applicants,
especially pro se applicants, may become confused by automatically obtaining a
travel benefit, when in fact they may be subjecting themselves to a statutory bar
by traveling; and (3) assuming that EAD cards and travel documents must be
issued upon payment of the blanket fee (the Applicant should get what s/he pays
for) this implies a production cost incurred and a diversion of production output,
whether the benefit has been actually requested by the Applicant or not.
The proposal attempts to justify the fee increase by asserting, ?when comparing
the fees applicants pay today for adjustment of status and interim benefits versus
the proposed single fee for adjustment of status [$905], the difference is far less
significant.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4911-12. In other words, USCIS claims that the
elimination of fees for interim benefits mitigates the severity of the overall fee
increase. The claim that applicants will benefit from the consolidation of fees
relies, however, on several invalid assumptions.
First, numerous Adjustment of Status Applicants, including minor children,
pregnant mothers, and elderly applicants, neither want nor need employment
authorization and / or permission to travel. Under the Proposed Rule, these
applicants will be required to pay for interim benefits they will never use. This calls
into question the validity of USCIS?s claim that the merging of fees makes the
increase less severe. Indeed, fees for these applicants will increase by nearly
300%, forcing them to pay for unnecessary or unwanted benefits, or precluding
their access to USCIS services entirely.
The USCIS also applies a somewhat circular argument to justify its proposed
$905.00 price tag for Adjustment of Status. If it charges the higher fee, it argues,
the agency will be able to adjudicate more efficiently and faster. However, the
USCIS is already, to its credit, adjudicating most Adjustment cases within six
months or less of filing. This improved service, which can and should be
maintained through appropriations, actually eliminates the need for interim benefits
for most applicants. But now, the Proposed Rule wants to build in a blanket
charge, purportedly to cover interim benefits no longer needed by most applicants
because of increased efficiency.
Whether to apply for interim benefits should remain a decision made by
applicants, based on the current circumstances and needs of the applicants, not
according to an automatic determination made by USCIS.
Another reason the Proposed Rule presents for merging interim benefits fees with
the Adjustment of Status fee is to counteract ?perceptions of impediments to
efficiency.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4894. The Proposed Rule argues that because ?the
longer cases take to adjudicate, the more total revenue is collected,? there may
exist a ?perception that USCIS gains by processing cases slowly.? Id. The
existence of alleged perceptions that the agency intentionally delays processing
hardly seems a material rationale justifying such drastic and unconscionable
changes.
In any event, this entire rationale must fail because it is premised, again, on a
flawed premise. The Proposed Rule states, ?This change [imbedding interim
benefits into the Adjustment of Status fee automatically] addresses the historic
perception that because of the Congressional requirement that USCIS be self-
funded from fees, USCIS may make decisions that compromise operational
efficiency to ensure revenue flow.? 72 Fed. Reg. 4894.
As clearly established above, the USCIS has never, at any time, been under
any such Congressional ?mandate? or ?requirement.? Indeed, as established
above, operational efficiency is a governmental and public objective that is
exclusively amenable to Congressional appropriation.

V.CONCLUSIONS.
Because the Proposed Rule exceeds and violates the statutory authority
provided in 8 U.S.C. ? 1356 for setting and collecting IEFA special benefits fees,
and misapplies OMB and FASAB guidelines, it cannot be legally adopted as a
Final Rule and must be abandoned.
Under IEFA, the USCIS must calculate the full costs of immigration
adjudication and naturalization services, surcharges, and IEFA handling costs
exclusively, and may not introduce the direct and indirect costs of its
governmental and public service activities in calculating these specific special
benefits costs.
USCIS must proactively seek and acquire Congressional appropriations to
excellently sustain and upgrade its governmental operations and public service
mission and mandates.
Congress, for its part, must fund the governmental operations and public
service provisions of any federal agency it creates, including the USCIS, and must
fund all needful infrastructure and operations upgrades, and public service
enhancements, that it directly or indirectly mandates.
IEFA may properly support all VAWA self-petitions and T-visa applications
through IEFA surcharges.
Whether to apply for interim benefits should remain the exclusive choice of the
individual Adjustment of Status Applicant and should not be automatically
embedded into an inflated blanket Adjustment fee.

Thank you for taking this Comment under your careful consideration.
Respectfully submitted,
